abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability is likely, and institutional
            development impacts are substantial. The dominance of the
            project in the health sector, mainly because of the
            magnitude of its investments relative to the implementing
            agencies' budgets, led to an absence of incentives in
            seeking efficient endemic disease controls; for its value,
            based on funding public health programs, did not improve
            resources management. Interestingly, only by the end of the
            project, did the Ministry of Health achieve some savings, by
            limiting the use of per diem, or travel expenses, to instead
            integrate disease control activities into the regular work,
            successfully increasing community participation. Neither was
            evaluation stimulated, which despite not being included in
            the design, little motivation existed for monitoring and
            evaluation. Thus, the lack of attention to performance
            indicators, and evaluation hindered institutional
            strengthening, whereas the Bank could have promoted
            meaningful evaluation, had resource allocation been
            contingent to impact indicators. Moreover, the lack of
            gradual shifts in recurrent costs to the national
            counterpart funds, led to missed opportunities in enhancing
            sustainability of endemic disease control activities.
            Finally, the introduction of international competitive
            bidding processes provided far lower prices, which may well
            sustain purchases of pesticides, drugs, or high cost
            consumables, as opposed to prior costs.
